title: :recycle: Re-authenticate only with custom auth token
message:
:recycle: Re-authenticate only with custom auth token

It's important to understand that AccountManager is not an encryption
service or a keychain. It stores account credentials just as you pass
them, in plain text. On most devices, this isn't a particular concern,
because it stores them in a database that is only accessible to root.
But on a rooted device, the credentials would be readable by anyone with
adb access to the device.

With this in mind, the account password will no longer be stored in the
account manager. The re-authentication will happend using the custom
auth token obtained from AccountManager.peekToken.

Given a token is obtained from the cache, for the sake of simplicity:

  - The expiration datetime will not be checked.
  - The token will be cached indefinitely until the app explicitely
    invidates it (i.e. customTokens=false).
  - If the sign in fails, the user will be prompted to the authenticator
    activity.

References:

  - Google Firebase Authentication
    See https://firebase.google.com/docs/auth/android/manage-users

  - Google Android Documentation - KEY_CUSTOM_TOKEN_EXPIRY
    See https://goo.gl/Xtk053

  - AccountManager.peekAuthToken returning null value.
    See http://www.stackoverflow.com/questions/29657289

  - Do Firebase tokens expire?
    See http://www.stackoverflow.com/questions/39091833/

  - JSON Web Tokens documentation
    See https://jwt.io/introduction/

  - RS256 vs HS256: What's the difference?
    See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/39239051

  - Google Training - Custom Auth: Be Smart about Security!
    https://developer.android.com/training/id-auth/custom_auth.html

title: :sparkles: Sign in using token stored in account manager
message:
:sparkles: Sign in using token stored in account manager

Given a (email, password) pair is provided to sign up a new account (or
just sign in into an existing one) at Firebase Authentication service, a
JSON web token will be obtained (RSA Signature with SHA-256) in a
successful authentication.

When the app requires to re-authenticate, instead of providing once more
the (email, password) pair, it can use the custom token while it is valid.

The expiration datetime can be obtained decoding the JWT token and could
be send to the authenticator activity using KEY_CUSTOM_TOKEN_EXPIRY.

Once the token is expired, the re-authentication happens providing once
more (email, password) pair, where the password can be obtained from
Android account manager or by user input.

References:

  - Google Firebase Authentication
    See https://firebase.google.com/docs/auth/android/manage-users

  - Google Android Documentation - KEY_CUSTOM_TOKEN_EXPIRY
    See https://goo.gl/Xtk053

  - AccountManager.peekAuthToken returning null value.
    See http://www.stackoverflow.com/questions/29657289

  - Do Firebase tokens expire?
    See http://www.stackoverflow.com/questions/39091833/

  - JSON Web Tokens documentation
    See https://jwt.io/introduction/

  - RS256 vs HS256: What's the difference?
    See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/39239051

title: :wrench: Android Keystore configuration
message:
:wrench: Android Keystore configuration

In order to create an account at Google Firebase, the application must be
propertly signed and the SHA1 fingerprint and package name authorized on
Firebase console.

References:
  - How can I create a keystore? (at stackoverflow.com/questions/3997748/)
  - SHA-1 fingerprint of keystore (at stackoverflow.com/questions/15727912/)
  - Firebase Authentication (at https://firebase.google.com/docs/auth/)

title: :lipstick: Sort attributes and methods
message:
:lipstick: Sort attributes and methods

Classes attributes are sorted according:
  - Visibility (public, protected, package protected and private)
  - Ascending lexicographical order
